Speaker: beck
Dialogue: Carl.

Speaker: goerdeler
Dialogue: I DEMAND THAT WE RELIEVE COLONEL STAUFFENBERG.

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: Carl, if I may have a word with you in private.

Speaker: goerdeler
Dialogue: If you have something to say, Ludwig, say it here. Say it now.

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: Very well. There's no need to vote.

Speaker: goerdeler
Dialogue: Wha... What are you saying?

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: Fellgiebel informed me this evening... Himmler's issued an order for your arrest. You'll have to leave Germany. Tonight. When we've succeeded with the central solution you'll return as Chancellor. Until then-

Speaker: goerdeler
Dialogue: This is your doing, isn't it? ISN'T IT? You can't just get rid of me like this. I am the man Germany will follow. I'm... I...

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: Disappear, Carl. Avoid contact with anyone.

Speaker: olbricht
Dialogue: I can't issue Valkyrie again unless we follow through. If he fails to-

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: I'll do my job. You just take Berlin.

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: Gentlemen, may I introduce Chief Helldorf. He's guaranteed the full support of the Berlin Police.

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: Gentlemen, this is the most important day of your lives. Long live sacred Germany.

Speaker: mertz
Dialogue: Put the Reserve Army on standby alert.

Speaker: olbricht
Dialogue: Not until I hear from Stauffenberg. Not until I'm sure.

Speaker: mertz
Dialogue: But that's not what he-

Speaker: olbricht
Dialogue: Noted, Colonel. Thank you.

Speaker: freyend
Dialogue: Gentlemen, may I present Colonel Claus von Stauffenberg - Chief Officer of the Reserve Army.

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: Indeed. I've got the whole bag of tricks right here.

Speaker: freyend
Dialogue: Let me take that for you.

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: Yes, sir, there is. I'm expecting a call of the utmost importance. Even if it comes when I am in conference with the Fhrer I'd appreciate it if you had a man come and get me.

Speaker: fellgiebel
Dialogue: Of course, Colonel.

Speaker: keitel
Dialogue: Gentlemen. The meeting has been pushed forward to 12:30. Mussolini is arriving on the afternoon train and Hitler wants to have lunch with him.

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: Will Mussolini be in the briefing?

Speaker: keitel
Dialogue: I only wish he were. Then some ambitious officer might take the opportunity to shoot the dago bastard.

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: I'll need a place to wash up - change my shirt.

Speaker: freyend
Dialogue: Please, do be quick. You heard the General.

Speaker: haeften
Dialogue: You're arming them... now?

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: No room for error this time. Assume I have ten minutes in this heat.

Speaker: haeften
Dialogue: Leaving just three minutes to place the bomb.

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: Plenty of time.

Speaker: haeften
Dialogue: If the bomb goes off in ten.

Speaker: freyend
Dialogue: Major Freyend speaking.  Stauffenberg? Yes, he's arrived... They are on their way now.

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: Dammit man, what is it?

Speaker: freyend
Dialogue: General Keitel insists that the Colonel please hurry.

Speaker: haeften
Dialogue: The Colonel is changing, Major. You understand this can be difficult.

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: See that the car is ready.

Speaker: haeften
Dialogue: But sir-

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: I have everything I need, Lieutenant. Thank you.

Speaker: freyend
Dialogue: Please. Let me help you with that.

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: I can manage, thank you.

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: Where are they going?

Speaker: freyend
Dialogue: It's too hot. The briefing has been moved to the conference hut.

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: My injuries left me a bit hard of hearing. See that you place me as near the Fhrer as possible.

Speaker: general
Dialogue: The Eastern Front forces are assured a victory... but they need reinforcements.

Speaker: keitel
Dialogue: Please pardon our tardiness... You remember Colonel Stauffenberg?

Speaker: general
Dialogue: As you can see, Mein Fhrer, the situation in the East Prussian sector is increasingly critical...

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: General Fellgiebel, sir. He says it's urgent.

Speaker: general
Dialogue: ...And now I believe Colonel Stauffenberg will present us with his deployment for the Replacement Army should the unthinkable occur and the Russians reach-

Speaker: freyend
Dialogue: Where the hell is Stauffenberg?

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: Contact General Olbricht in Berlin. Tell him Hitler is dead. Proceed with Operation Valkyrie. Then sever all communications.

Speaker: communications officer
Dialogue: What the hell just happened?

Speaker: fellgiebel
Dialogue: What does it look like? The Fhrer is-

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: We have to get to the airfield at once. Orders form the Fhrer.

Speaker: fellgiebel
Dialogue: Sever all communications.

Speaker: communications officer
Dialogue: Sir?

Speaker: fellgiebel
Dialogue: DON'T ARGUE WITH ME, DAMMIT. JUST DO IT.

Speaker: mertz
Dialogue: I didn't hear you. Come again. Fellgiebel. FELLGIEBEL.

Speaker: olbricht
Dialogue: Well, what did he say?

Speaker: mertz
Dialogue: I... couldn't be sure. It sounded as though he said... Hitler is still alive.

Speaker: olbricht
Dialogue: Get him back on the line.

Speaker: mertz
Dialogue: Sir... The bomb did go off. That much was clear. Fellgiebel's next step will be to sever all communications.

Speaker: olbricht
Dialogue: Only Fromm can initiate. You know that.

Speaker: mertz
Dialogue: Then lie. Tell him Hitler's dead. Or arrest him. But do it now.

Speaker: olbricht
Dialogue: I'm not doing anything until I talk to Fellgiebel. Get him back on the phone. NOW.

Speaker: kolbe
Dialogue: No one gets in or out.

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: We're on orders from the Fhrer. We have to get to the airfield immediately. You will step aside.

Speaker: kolbe
Dialogue: I'm sorry, sir, but my orders are-

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: Get me General Keitel.

Speaker: kolbe
Dialogue: Kolbe.

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: Sergeant Kolbe says no one is getting out... Yes. Yes. Maybe you can explain it to him.

Speaker: kolbe
Dialogue: That won't be necessary, Colonel.

Speaker: olbricht
Dialogue: I can't initiate Valkyrie without confirmation that Hitler's dead. It's too great a risk.

Speaker: mertz
Dialogue: What about Stauffenberg? What about his risk? He did his part and now you're abandoning him.

Speaker: olbricht
Dialogue: Watch yourself, Colonel.

Speaker: mertz
Dialogue: Shouldn't you be consulting Beck?

Speaker: olbricht
Dialogue: I know just what Beck will say. He's a dying man. What does he have to lose?

Speaker: mertz
Dialogue: At least put the Reserve Army on alert.

Speaker: olbricht
Dialogue: I can't cover up another false alarm. When Stauffenberg returns, when he gives me confirmation. Then we'll proceed.

Speaker: mertz
Dialogue: And where are you going?

Speaker: olbricht
Dialogue: The same place you are. Lunch.

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: The one-eyed Colonel...

Speaker: keitel
Dialogue: Stauffenberg.

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: He left the building very abruptly - just before the explosion.

Speaker: keitel
Dialogue: Several men left the building before the explosion.

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Yes, sir. Of course. But...

Speaker: keitel
Dialogue: But what? Spit it out, man.

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Well. The Colonel left his hat.

Speaker: freyend
Dialogue: Pardon the intrusion, sir, but I think you will be most interested to hear what this man has to say.

Speaker: mertz
Dialogue: Orders from General Olbricht.

Speaker: helm
Dialogue: Send it through. But keep me informed.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Here we go again.

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: Quiet, isn't it?

Speaker: haeften
Dialogue: I'll see where our driver is.

Speaker: olbricht
Dialogue: Explain this.

Speaker: mertz
Dialogue: Someone had to do something while you were playing dead.

Speaker: olbricht
Dialogue: We don't know that the Fhrer is not alive. We don't know any-

Speaker: mertz
Dialogue: THIS IS ABOUT GERMANY, FOR GOD'S SAKE. NOT YOU. BE A MAN.

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: It's been three hours, Olbricht. What the hell have you been doing?

Speaker: olbricht
Dialogue: We've had no confirmation that-

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: Dammit man, I saw the explosion myself. Nothing else matters now. We are committed.

Speaker: olbricht
Dialogue: Dear God.

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: Now where is Fromm? Is he with us or did you-

Speaker: olbricht
Dialogue: I- No one has spoken to him yet.

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: Listen to me, Olbricht. Never mind Germany. Never mind Europe. Your life is at stake now, do you understand? If you want to live through the night you'll do exactly as I say.

Speaker: olbricht
Dialogue: I understand.

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: The second you hang up the phone, initiate Operation Valkyrie in Fromm's name. Then go over to his office in force, give him the choice to join us or place him under immediate arrest. Do I make myself perfectly clear?

Speaker: olbricht
Dialogue: I understand.

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: I am at the airfield now. I will be in Fromm's office in fifteen minutes. Be there when I arrive.

Speaker: olbricht
Dialogue: Get Beck and the others. Tell them it's time.

Speaker: helm
Dialogue: The Fhrer is dead.

Speaker: haans
Dialogue: You all know your jobs. Get to work.

Speaker: operator
Dialogue: Sergeant. This order is signed by Witzleben.

Speaker: helm
Dialogue: That's ridiculous. He`s not even in the army anymore.

Speaker: olbricht
Dialogue: General Fellgiebel. At the Wolf's Lair.

Speaker: olbricht
Dialogue: There's no use calling, all communication lines are-

Speaker: keitel
Dialogue: I don't know what you mean. Everything's in order here.

Speaker: fromm
Dialogue: There's talk the Fhrer's been assassinated.

Speaker: keitel
Dialogue: Another failed attempt. The Fhrer was never in danger.  By the way, where is your man Colonel Stauffenberg?

Speaker: fromm
Dialogue: Stauffenberg? On his way back to Berlin, I should think.

Speaker: fromm
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: Hitler is dead. Operation Valkyrie is in effect.

Speaker: fromm
Dialogue: OPERATION VAL- WHO GAVE THE ORDER?

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: You did.

Speaker: fromm
Dialogue: THIS IS NOTHING LESS THAN TREASON.

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: Be that as it may, the Reserve Army is assuming control here in Berlin. We trust you'll join us.

Speaker: fromm
Dialogue: Dammit, man. Do you realize what you've done? The Fhrer is a-

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: I delivered the bomb myself. I saw the blast. He is dead.

Speaker: fromm
Dialogue: This can't be happening. It's some kind of joke.

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: Are you with us or not?

Speaker: fromm
Dialogue: Colonel, if what you say is true you should shoot yourself at once.  The rest of you are under arrest.

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: No, General. You are.

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: Lock him upstairs in his private quarters. Make sure his phone lines are cut.

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: You're not in uniform.

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: This has to be seen as a movement of the people.

Speaker: young officer
Dialogue: Colonel Stauffenberg, sir. We're reporting for duty.

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: Helldorf, I'm... glad to see you. We're getting a late start and we need all of the manpower we can muster. Can we count on the police?

Speaker: helldorf
Dialogue: There's a lot of talk that Hitler isn't really dead. Is this true?

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: I can't offer you any guarantees. The decision is yours and yours alone. Can we count on you?

Speaker: helldorf
Dialogue: I'm with you.

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: Have your men surround the building. No one gets in or out of here without my permission.  I want every available soldier on task - we need simultaneous control of every government building in the city. Dismissed.

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: Acts of vengeance will not be tolerated. We represent a different form of government. We represent what is good and just in Germany.

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: ...Deploy troops to seize and protect all Reich agencies. Of most importance are communication centers - newspapers, radio stations, telephone and telegraph offices. All Nazi officials and government leaders are to be arrested at once...

Speaker: hase
Dialogue: ... Completely blockade the government quarters. Everything from the Brandenburg Gate to Potsdamer Platz. Nobody, not even generals or ministers, should be allowed to pass.  You have your orders, gentlemen.

Speaker: remer
Dialogue: It just all seems very... vague, sir. Protocol dictates we should receive orders in writing-

Speaker: hase
Dialogue: These are the orders as they were presented to me, Major. Now move.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Major Remer. We've just had orders from the War Ministry. The battalion is to blockade the government quarter and place Minister Goebbels under arrest.

Speaker: remer
Dialogue: Something just doesn't feel right about this. I would hate to find out I'm being taken advantage of.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: A coup you think?

Speaker: remer
Dialogue: Of that I am certain. What I can't say is which side we're on. Get in.

Speaker: fat general
Dialogue: Begging your pardon, but I have orders to report to General Fromm.

Speaker: olbricht
Dialogue: General Fromm is no longer in command. I am.

Speaker: fat general
Dialogue: I...  Beck? What are you- What is going on here?

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: The Fhrer is dead. The SS is staging a coup. We've initiated Operation Valkyrie to crush the uprising and save Hitler's Germany.

Speaker: fat general
Dialogue: I'd say there is a coup all right, but it's not the SS.

Speaker: olbricht
Dialogue: You will present these orders to your troops.

Speaker: fat general
Dialogue: I will do no such thing without speaking to General Fromm. I swore an oath-

Speaker: fat general
Dialogue: This is treason. I won't take part. The Fhrer is not dead. THE FHRER IS NOT DEAD.  The Fat General makes a break for it. The conspirators chase him out into...

Speaker: olbricht
Dialogue: STOP THAT MAN.

Speaker: fat general
Dialogue: THE FHRER IS NOT DEAD. I'VE SWORN AN OATH. YOU ALL HAVE...

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: Lt. Herber. Come here.

Speaker: goebbels
Dialogue: I am ready to be connected.

Speaker: remer
Dialogue: Minister Goebbels, my battalion has an order to blockade the government quarter and place you under arrest.

Speaker: goebbels
Dialogue: Are you a dedicated Nazi, Major?

Speaker: remer
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: remer
Dialogue: Of course, Mein Fhrer.

Speaker: haans
Dialogue: What is it now, Sergeant?

Speaker: helm
Dialogue: It's just that now we're getting conflicting orders, sir. The Wolf's Lair says one thing, Stauffenberg another.

Speaker: haans
Dialogue: Our job is not to interpret the orders. Our job is to pass them along. Regardless.

Speaker: helm
Dialogue: Yes, but sir-

Speaker: haans
Dialogue: Is that perfectly clear, Sergeant?

Speaker: remer
Dialogue: Release these men at once.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: But these men are part of a coup.

Speaker: remer
Dialogue: I've just been on the phone with Hitler himself. We are the coup, you idiot. We've been duped.

Speaker: fromm
Dialogue: Well, Lieutenant. What do you make of all of this?

Speaker: herber
Dialogue: I... I don't know...

Speaker: fromm
Dialogue: I won't ask you to make a choice. That's for you and you alone. All I ask is that you observe and think for yourself. In time you'll see things for what they truly are. You know where to find me when you do.

Speaker: herber
Dialogue: Heil Hitler.

Speaker: goebbels
Dialogue: Have you seen the Fhrer? Is he-

Speaker: himmler
Dialogue: It seems the conference table shielded him from the blast. He's lucky to be alive.  Do you want to tell me what's going on?

Speaker: goebbels
Dialogue: Everything is under control. I've taken charge of the Guard Battalion and given them new orders. We're turning the tables on these cowards.

Speaker: himmler
Dialogue: I've been sent here personally by the Fhrer to collect the conspirators. He insists they be taken alive.

Speaker: goebbels
Dialogue: Take this down. By order of Adolf Hitler...

Speaker: helm
Dialogue: It's a coup all right... And when it's over, we'd better wind up on the right side. Now we can't afford to remain neutral any longer. We have to make a decision.

Speaker: haans
Dialogue: Very well. Send all communications from the Wolf's Lair. Stop all communications from Stauffenberg.

Speaker: radio announcer
Dialogue: ...The Fhrer himself suffered no major injuries and resumed his work immediately...

Speaker: stauffenberg
Dialogue: Send the following teleprint to all Army Commanders... `Broadcast communique not correct. The Fhrer is dead. Orders to be carried out with utmost dispatch.'

Speaker: witzleben
Dialogue: The military districts are receiving contradictory reports. I've got men sitting around joking about whose turn it is to arrest whom. Neither the capital nor the radio network are under our control. And where are the troops? You'd think there would be some activity going on in this city.  The word is all over the street that Hitler is still alive. We trusted you and you failed us. You should have stayed. To be sure.

Speaker: witzleben
Dialogue: I'm going home to await my inevitable arrest.

Speaker: herber
Dialogue: Arm yourselves.

Speaker: remer
Dialogue: YOU THERE.

Speaker: remer
Dialogue: You're under arrest.

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: I'd like a pistol, please.

Speaker: remer
Dialogue: General, my orders are to deliver the prisoners alive.

Speaker: fromm
Dialogue: Noted, Major.  Get on with it then.

Speaker: remer
Dialogue: But, sir-

Speaker: fromm
Dialogue: THAT WILL BE ALL, MAJOR.

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: I'm thinking of earlier times...
